questions.question: How does the PostHog JavaScript SDK implement token bucket rate limiting for different exception types?
options: Uses a single global token bucket for all exceptions
Uses separate independent token buckets for each exception type (TypeError, ReferenceError, etc.)
Uses a hierarchical bucketing system with exception type categories
Uses time-based rate limiting without token buckets

questions.question: What is the default token bucket configuration for exception rate limiting in the PostHog SDK?
options: Bucket size: 5 tokens, refill rate: 1 token per 5 seconds
Bucket size: 10 tokens, refill rate: 1 token per 10 seconds
Bucket size: 20 tokens, refill rate: 2 tokens per 10 seconds
Bucket size: 100 tokens, refill rate: 10 tokens per second

questions.question: Where is the exception type extracted from in the PostHog exception tracking pipeline?
options: From the error message string
From the stack trace filename
From errorProperties.$exception_list[0].type field
From the browser's native error classification

questions.question: How many separate rate limiting systems does the PostHog SDK implement?
options: One global rate limiter for all events
Two: exception-specific bucketed rate limiter and global event rate limiter
Three: per-type, per-domain, and global limiters
Four: per-type, per-domain, global, and server-side limiters

questions.question: What happens when a token bucket for a specific exception type is exhausted?
options: The exception is queued for later processing
The exception is dropped and a log message is generated
The exception is sent to a fallback bucket
The bucket is immediately refilled

questions.question: Which files contain the core implementation of bucketed rate limiting for exceptions?
options: Only /packages/browser/src/extensions/exception-autocapture/index.ts
/packages/core/src/utils/bucketed-rate-limiter.ts and /packages/browser/src/extensions/exception-autocapture/index.ts
Only /packages/core/src/error-tracking/coercers/
/packages/browser/src/request-queue.ts only

questions.question: Are exception rate limiting buckets independent from each other?
options: No, all exception types share tokens from a single bucket
Yes, each exception type has its own independent token bucket with separate token allocation
Partially, exception types are grouped into categories that share buckets
No, buckets are shared within the same error domain

questions.question: How is the exception type used in the rate limiting system?
options: It's used for logging purposes only
It's used as the bucket key for per-type rate limiting
It's used to determine the refill rate
It's used to select between different rate limiting algorithms

questions.question: What filtering layers exist after the token bucket rate limiting check?
options: Only server-side filtering
Suppression rules, extension exception filter, and SDK self-exception filter
Only extension exception filter
No additional filtering after rate limiting

questions.question: Is the exception rate limiting configuration customizable?
options: No, it uses hardcoded defaults
Yes, via error_tracking.__exceptionRateLimiterBucketSize and __exceptionRateLimiterRefillRate config options
Only the bucket size is customizable
Only the refill rate is customizable
